. It is conveniently located on the border to Liechtenstein and can easily be visited in an afternoon. It is nestled in a picturesque place where three valleys meet and includes a well preserved old town and the dominating edifice of the ancient Schattenburg Castle. While small in size, it is the most well preserved and scenic of Vorarlberg's cities. Many people make the mistake and pass through Feldkirch on their way to Liechtenstein or Innsbruck without even exploring its wonderful charm. Don't make this mistake!

value: content=Can offer advice on sightseeing, helps arrange accommodation, and sells tickets to special events and concerts. They have a good free map of the inner city, which is also available outside the office when it is closed.

Feldkirch lies in the Rhein Valley bordering Liechtenstein to the south and Switzerland to the west.
The closest international airports are in

value: to look up train information online. Storage lockers available.

From Germany and Bavaria you will take the

and cross at Lindau and continue southward. From Liechtenstein you simply head north. From Switzerland you have to cross east over the Rhein. From Tyrol and Innsbruck you will have to pass through the Arlberg Tunnel (toll) an incredibly scenic drive that takes you through the stunning Walgau Valley. The Arlberg Pass offers a free alternative but is only open in the warm weather months.
The old town centre is small, and easy to walk around. Most of the streets are pedestrianised. There is lots of parking available just outside the centre.

(in German); a route map is available
. Unfortunately the buses cannot accommodate bicycles.

price=Fare calculated by route and distance
content=An on-call nighttime 'maxi-taxi' service is available. Call at least 30 min beforehand.
hours=Jan-Mar T-F 13:30-16:00, Sa Su and holidays 11:00-16:00; Apr-Oct M-F 09:00-12:00, 13:30-17:00, Sa Su and hoilidays 10:00-17:00; Nov-Dec Sa Su and holidays 11:00-16:00

content=A 13th-century castle, on a hill to the east of the town and impossible to miss. It was once the seat of the Earls of Montfort. Today there is a local history museum and some restaurants inside.

content=The foundations of the church date to the 13th century. After suffering severe damage following serious fires, it was rebuilt in the Gothic style in 1478; it considered to be the most significant Gothic church in Vorarlberg.

content=City gates and defensive towers of the medieval city fortifications have been largely preserved, and are well-worth seeing. The city walls were demolished at the beginning of the 19th century.
content=Built in 1491 as part of the old city wall. This is also called the 'Salt Gate' (
), as until the turn of the last century salt was stored here.
content=This defensive tower, built in 1507, was once part of the town's fortifications. It is believed to be named after the canons (

) which were kept in the tower, as the targeting devices were shaped like lions' heads. In the early 17th century the building was converted into a bell tower; the current bell was poured in the 19th century and is the largest bell in Vorarlberg. The bell is rung on major holidays and on Fridays at 15:00 (
: believed to be the hour of Christ's death).
content=Built in the 15th century, this was once, as the name suggests, a prison. The city walls which once connected it to the other towers were demolished several decades ago.

content=The Pulverturm was built in 1460 and is the oldest of the city's four towers. As the name suggests, gunpowder was stored here. Today the tower is used as a meeting place by a local association.
content=This tower was built in 1482, and once had an entrance to the Ill River. This tower now also serves as a meeting place for a local club.
content=This building is now a music conservatory, but it used to be a Jesuit College. Arthur Conan Doyle, author of
content=Built in about 1260 by the Counts of Montfort, the castle has been abandoned since 1616. The ruins of the primary defensive tower (
) as well as parts of the palace are still standing, and are a favourite destination for hikers.

content=A 12th-century Romanesque church, with foundations dating to the 11th century. By the northern wall of the cemetery is a thousand-year-old year tree – the oldest tree in Vorarlberg and one of the oldest in Austria, with a circumference of 5 metres. The tree figures in a number of local legends, and was believed to have healing properties.
image=Marktplatz 2, hl Johannes der Täufer Feldkirch.JPG
content=This former church, originally built in the 13th century and modified in the 17th century, is now used as a venue for contemporary art installation pieces.
directions=next to the tourist information office
content=Hosts exhibits of contemporary modern art.
content=This former villa serves as a venue for exhibiting the work of a collective of regional artists. Currently about 40 artists participate.
Freedom stupa at the Letzehof Buddhist Monastery
View from the hiking trail on Stadtschrofen
directions=Stadtbus 7, or by foot from Liechtensteiner Straße and Duxgasse
hours=Prayer/meditation rooms, stupa: anytime; tour by appt

content=This Buddhist monastery was founded in 1982 by Geshe Rabten Rinpotsche, on the site of a former dairy. Resident monks include Tibetans, Mongolians, and Europeans. The monks hold regular seminars and evening lectures about meditation, and operate a small bookshop (daily 15:00-17:00). Several guest rooms are available for those interested in a meditation retreat.
price=General admission is free (does not include large concerts)

content=For six weeks every summer this festival offers numerous concerts, including Sunday morning Jazz concerts as well as such big name acts as Calexico, Heather Nova, Tocotronic, Shout Out Louds, dEUS, Kosheen, Coldcut, and others. Additional highlights include cinema, short films, cabaret performances, poetry slams, quiz programs, fashion shows, and discussion panels.

:The venues are completely rebuilt every year; designers are selected via an international architecture competition. Art and fashion competitions also enrich the festival.
content=Built in 1903, this is the oldest continuously-operating public pool in Vorarlberg.

content=The area around Feldkirch offers numerous hiking opportunities, with trails ranging in difficulty from short and easy to challenging full-day treks. Many of the trail heads can be reached by public bus. Some of the more popular routes include the Ardetzenberg, Stadtschrofen, and the Hohes and Niederes Känzele. The tourist office has excellent free hiking maps and can make additional suggestions.
content=Located in a historic building, this is where the popular Vorarlberg beer is produced. Brewery tours (in German) are available on request.
content=Located in the centre of town and renovated in 2012, with numerous shops.
content=Also has a small restaurant/café, with takeout available.

content=This street is a proper medieval German street, with its arches and covered walkways, and has been used as the town's central market area since the Middle Ages. A number of shops and cafés are located here, which also have outdoor seating during pleasant weather.
content=Well worth visiting. Vendors offer fresh produce, cheese, and flowers, as well as a large selection of food items imported from Italy and France.
hours=Apr-Nov: every 1st and 3rd Saturday of the month
content=Serves excellent traditional Austrian food and beers. In summer outside seating is available in a pleasant garden.
content=The western-most restaurant in Austria, offers traditional Austrian food.
hours=M-F 07:00-24:00, Sa 08:00-24:00; Su 14:00-19:00 (in winter; summer opening dependent on weather)
content=Offers a range of innovative and creative dishes, with many vegetarian options. Outside seating.
hours=Sep-Jun T-Sa 11:00-14:00, 15:00-22:00, Su and holidays 11:00-14:00, 15:00-21:00, closed M; Jul-Aug also open on M
content=One of the best-known restaurants in Feldkirch, well-known for their giant Schnitzel as well as other traditional dishes.
content=Really delicious and great value pasta and pizza, in a cosy restaurant. Outdoor seating available in the summer.

In the last few years a number of pleasant cafés have been established, inviting the visitor to linger awhile.

value: content=A café/bar/lounge and furniture store. Free wi-fi.

content=Also has a good restaurant offering regional specialties.
content=Very conveniently located in the city centre, this is a family-operated hotel.
name=Best Western Plus Central Hotel Leonhard
content=The 700-year-old building is a former infirmary and has been recently renovated. Open year round, reception 07:00-23:00, no curfew, free wi-fi.
content=Just 10km to the north and worth a visit, easily accessible by car, bus, or train.
content=This church is particularly noteworthy, and was founded as a fortified church in the 8th century; portions of the defensive walls still remain. It is now a pilgrimage destination.
content=A unique open air museum with the remains of a Roman estate dating from the 1st-5th centuries BCE. An online
(in German) outlines the history of the site.

, one of the smallest countries in the world, is only a few kilometres away.
